timeline.Text: I was the first person that DataXstream hired when the two founders decided to grow their business. I learned everything I could about the technology used in SAP projects and helped as a consultant on some of their projects after my skills had developed. I performed a system copy of SAP 4.6c, configured interfaces using SAP ALE and IDocs between SAP and non-SAP systems, and performed basic mapping with SAP PI. I installed SAP XI 2.0, which at the time was poorly documented and had several major installation bugs that I had to work through on my own. Most of my learning was self-taught, but I had a great furtune of being able to ask questions to some of the most experienced consultants in the game. This company has since grown into a successful consulting business, and I have worked with them on several occasions as an independent.
timeline.Title: DataXstream

timeline.Text: Wolseley was doing an SAP implementation (at the time, it was SAP's largest new account) and was building their internal competency in various technical skillsets. I was brought on because I had previous experience on the basis side of the house, but also had some hands on experience with integration using IDocs and SAP PI. During my time there, I took on as much technical work as I could and ultimately learned SAP MDM at a time when not very many people knew the product.
timeline.Title: Wolseley

timeline.Text: I started as a technical consultant and received two promotions in two years making me the youngest principal consultant in the company at the time. My focus areas were SAP Master Data Management (and the surrounding processes and modules), SAP XI/PI and ancilliary technologies leveraged for building interfaces between systems, and various web technologies for designing and building user-interfaces that were abstracted from the backend systems. During my time there, I also worked closely with SAP Labs on several initiatives and gained insight towards the development process at SAP. I also mentored junior consultants, and presented seminars at conferences demonstrating innovative ways to use the technology.
timeline.Title: SAP

timeline.Text: Kraft Foods was implementing SAP MDM as an early adopter and I was originally brought on to backfill a consultant who was going on vacation during a critical phase of the project. However, the customer was happy with my work and kept me on to help in other areas, such as the configuration of the transport system for SAP PI.
timeline.Title: Kraft Foods

timeline.Text: Applied Materials did a full-scale conversion from Oracle ERP to SAP ERP that included nearly the entire suite of SAP products. One large component of the project was the data conversion and data management peice. I was the lead on that part of the project and was able to take them live with SAP MDM, SAP EP, and SAP PI on a solution that allowed them to govern and centrally manage the material, customer, and vendor master data domains. This included the security role design and governance structure, process design and implementation via workflow, configuration of web-based views using SAP Enterprise Portal and on occasion some custom views using Java WebDynpro and the MDM Java API, interfaces to multiple systems using SAP PI, and a consolidated data set for the conversion loads into SAP ERP.One of the most interesting parts of this project was the fact that the customer identified gaps in the product which needed to be addressed with SAP Labs, the development side of SAP. We worked together to spec out the missing functionality and were able to roll this into a future release of the product to address the customer's needs. Further, much of the work with Applied Materials gave me a unique insight into the demands of customers, which allowed me to work on a future product of SAP's called MDG.
timeline.Title: Applied Materials

timeline.Text: Sysco Foods was undergoing a large SAP implementation which had the unique scenario of running an advanced MDM initiative in parallel to their project. This is to say, they had two parallel MDM projects occuring at the same time, and I was responsible for the first wave. The objective of this project was to cleanse and consolidate as much of the data across their global operations, wherein every state operation much like a distinct company code.The existing platform was a homegrown legacy system wherein each instance (for each U.S. state) was a completely seperate database that did not have well designed integration architecture. Therefore, the project was unique from most SAP MDM projects in that it largely focused around harmonizing a legacy landscape rather than integrating with an SAP environment.
timeline.Title: Sysco Foods

timeline.Text: Founded Holland Systems, which grew into a multi-million dollar consulting company.
timeline.Title: Holland Systems

timeline.Text: Mylan had a global SAP implementation which included Master Data Management for the finance domains. I was responsible for all of the design, build, and support of the MDM solution. This included G/L Accounts, Cost Centers, Profit Centers, as well as the primary and secondary cost elements. The solution included a set of comprehensive workflow processes built with SAP CE/BPM and custom Java Webdynpro objects for the user interfaces. My responsibilities also included the facilitation of the integration development and testing - which included development in SAP PI and configuration of the ALE layer in SAP. Additionally, I was responsible for the development of the security and governance model, including the development of security roles in several SAP products.On this project I was sub-contracted by the lead implementer and represented their company, however their entire team was based in Zurich so I was the only resource in the United States where much of the decision making (from the customer side) took place. Therefore, my role also incorporated a lot of customer relationship management and general project management activities.
timeline.Title: Mylan Pharmaceuticals

timeline.Text: Mylan had a global SAP implementation which included Master Data Management for the finance domains. I was responsible for all of the design, build, and support of the MDM solution. This included G/L Accounts, Cost Centers, Profit Centers, as well as the primary and secondary cost elements. The solution included a set of comprehensive workflow processes built with SAP CE/BPM and custom Java Webdynpro objects for the user interfaces. My responsibilities also included the facilitation of the integration development and testing - which included development in SAP PI and configuration of the ALE layer in SAP. Additionally, I was responsible for the development of the security and governance model, including the development of security roles in several SAP products.On this project I was sub-contracted by the lead implementer and represented their company, however their entire team was based in Zurich so I was the only resource in the United States where much of the decision making (from the customer side) took place. Therefore, my role also incorporated a lot of customer relationship management and general project management activities.
timeline.Title: Mylan Pharmaceuticals

timeline.Text: The Coca-Cola Company was merging with Coca-Cola Refreshments and forming a new operating entity (Coca-Cola Enterprises). Traditionally the Coca-Cola Company made the syrup as their final product, which was then sold to independent bottlers who in turn would convert that to the final drinking product during the bottling process before distribution. Because of the merge there were some interesting data challenges faced due to the fact that the bottlers were previously viewed as a customer of the company, and the finished product of one was the raw material of another. I was brought on to assist with the design of a data architecture that would encompass the enourmous landscape of business systems that produced and consumer master data between the two organizations. This involved analysis and integrations of several hundred systems which all needed a single source of truth. Additionally, I designed the governance structure that incorporated roles and responsibilities - including the design of the security model for managing master data objects.
timeline.Title: Coca-Cola

timeline.Text: Gerdau Ameristeel was in the middle of a full-scale implementation of SAP when I was brought on to assist with the EDI component of their project. The work almost exclusively centered around SAP PI development for mappings, but also included ALE/IDoc configuration within SAP ERP, and configuration of the EDI message broker called Crossgate (which was an SAP acquisition that has since been retired). I personally developed, tested, and supported a large portion of the interfaces including the 404 810, 850, 856, and 997 (among others).
timeline.Title: Gerdau

timeline.Text: American Greetings had a multi-year SAP initiative and engaged my company for a large portion of the technical work. The scope of activities were wide, including (but not limited to) Solution Manager configuration of retrofit and ChaRM - with the rollout of an n1 landscape. SAP Identity Management was integrated into the HR modules of SAP and IBM's TAM LDAP to seamlessly provision new and modified users throughout the landscape. SAP MDM was used in conjuction with BusinessObjects Data Services to consolidate, cleanse, and convert legacy data - and serve data to a custom web initiative. Enterprise Portal was implemented as the unified user-interface / front-end to simplify the management of equipment and helpdesk activitieis. SAP CE was heavily used for building cross-system workflow processes. SAP PI was used as the middleware for all interfaces in and out of SAP ERP.I was personally involved in all of the aforementioned activities, however the areas which I was most heavily involved were the SAP IdM / security architecture, the SAP Master Data Management implementation, various basis activities (installations, upgrades, etc.), and I did all of the configuration of their Enterprise Portal.
timeline.Title: American Greetings

timeline.Text: Re-branded Holland Systems into Big Concepts
timeline.Title: BigConcepts

timeline.Text: Began working on Solo, a full-scale business software system which can dynamically generate user-interface content, has a dynamically adjustable database, and dynamically-driven application logic - all of which work together to provide a platform that will scale on demand and learn from it's mistakes.  This project is still ongoing.
timeline.Title: SOLO

timeline.Text: JimmyAsh is a disruptive startup with a proprietary manufacturing process enabling them to produce significantly healthier snack foods. They had secured contracts with several large customers long before a production run of their factory, and therefore were in a uniquely challenging position. They needed to meet the demands of Fortune 1000 customers but with the staff and funding of a typical startup. My company became their IT partner assisting with evaluation and purchasing of IT equipment, negotiating and coordinating with other IT vendors (such as telecom), physically networking their offices and plants, providing technical support to their end-users, and also evaluating small to mid-sized ERP solutions and negotiating a price and implementation that was a fraction of the cost most would expect.Because of the intellectual property concerns, another big part of our engagement was designing a holistic security architecture that included zoned networks (firewall configuration / VPN configuration), encrypted hard-drives and email communication, encrypted backups and disaster recovery solutions, roles and responsibilities designed throughout their business applications, and user provisioning with strong systematically enforced passphrases.
timeline.Title: JimmyAsh

timeline.Text: JimmyAsh is a disruptive startup with a proprietary manufacturing process enabling them to produce significantly healthier snack foods. They had secured contracts with several large customers long before a production run of their factory, and therefore were in a uniquely challenging position. They needed to meet the demands of Fortune 1000 customers but with the staff and funding of a typical startup. My company became their IT partner assisting with evaluation and purchasing of IT equipment, negotiating and coordinating with other IT vendors (such as telecom), physically networking their offices and plants, providing technical support to their end-users, and also evaluating small to mid-sized ERP solutions and negotiating a price and implementation that was a fraction of the cost most would expect.Because of the intellectual property concerns, another big part of our engagement was designing a holistic security architecture that included zoned networks (firewall configuration / VPN configuration), encrypted hard-drives and email communication, encrypted backups and disaster recovery solutions, roles and responsibilities designed throughout their business applications, and user provisioning with strong systematically enforced passphrases.
timeline.Title: JimmyAsh

timeline.Text: LambWeston was performing a carve-out from Conagra as they were performing a split into a distinctly separate legal entity, and needed to be independently free from the IT infrastructure of their former company. The timeline was very aggressive due to regulatory reasons in which certain dates had to be hit to prevent financial impact. The project was largely centered around a series of system clone procedures to copy the source ERP systems into a new landscape. Following this, the database needed to be stripped of any Conagra-sensative information. Additionally, interfaces (including EDI) had to be rebuilt from the ground up, conversion/load programs had to be developed, some minor modifications made to existing ABAP enhancements, security roles had to be completely redesigned (and integrated with external HR system), and workflows required updating.This was a unique project in that the complexity largely centered around reverse-engineering some rather 'exotic' customizations within the SAP landscape to ensure they would still be operational on the new system. To further complicate things, there was also a migration to SAP HANA that took place as part of the system clone procedure - further increasing the risk that customizations may not work due to underlying database and architectural platform changes. Despite a significantly understaffed team (less than 15 experienced resources) and a massively tight timeline, the project went live with a delay of just one week.
timeline.Title: LambWeston
